description: Borrowed from Latin temperatura (cf. also French température), from the past participle stem of tempero (“I temper”).

entries.meaning: A measure of cold or heat, often measurable with a thermometer.
examples: The boiling temperature of pure water is 100 degrees Celsius.
The temperature in the room dropped nearly 20 degrees; it went from hot to cold.
The most accurate way to take your temperature is by sticking a thermometer up your butt.

entries.meaning: An elevated body temperature, as present in fever and many illnesses.
examples: You have a temperature. I think you should stay home today. You’re sick.

entries.meaning: (thermodynamics) A property of macroscopic amounts of matter that serves to gauge the average intensity of the random actual motions of the individually mobile particulate constituents. [1]
(obsolete) The state or condition of being tempered or moderated.
(now rare, archaic) The balance of humours in the body, or one's character or outlook as considered determined from this; temperament.
examples: Our intemperence it is that pulls so many several incurable diseases on our heads, that hastens old age, perverts our temperature, and brings upon us sudden death.
